awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Reputation as Public Policy for Internet Security
awd_abstract_narration:
Internet miscreants cooperate for profit in identity theft, denial of service, etc.  Meanwhile, defending organizations act separately and treat Internet information security (infosec) as a cost to be minimized.  Customers could choose more wisely among competing Internet firms if they knew which had good or bad security, and such fame or shame would cause firms to improve security to retain and attract customers.

To verify such a policy of peer influence, this project uses a readily available stand-in for organizational infosec: outbound spam (unsolicited bulk email).  Other security problems may not cause outbound spam, and this project makes no claims to solve all problems.  However, just as a sneeze indicates disease, spam indicates poor infosec that could be exploited for even worse purposes (theft, denial of service, blackmail, etc.), and no organization wants to be seen to have such problems.

The project ranks similar organizations in SpamRankings.net, using daily data from multiple anti-spam blocklists, aggregating it from IP addresses into routing blocks (Autonomous Systems), and categorizing their owners by geography and type (hosting, medical, ISP, etc.).  Field experiments, including the relative effects of different publicity strategies, seek to determine whether publishing information on a symptom of infosec (outbound spam) causes firms to improve that symptom.

Positive experimental results will serve as stepping stones to policy recommendations of legislative mandates of timely and publicly accessible incident disclosure to enable more third-party peer rankings for further infosec improvement.  Minimal enforcement could thus catalyze significant improvements in Internet usability, profitability, and national security.

por.por_cntn:
We proposed that various policies can be implemented to alleviate the negative externalities and information asymmetry problem of cybersecurity, which can generate su?cient motivations for organizations to invest more on their security management. Theoretically, we propose two cybersecurity risk management approaches: risk pooling arrangements (RPAs) and managed security services (MSSs). Our results show that ?rms can use an RPA as a complement to cyber-insurance to address the overinvestment issue caused by negative externalities of security investments. In addition, the MSS provider serving multiple ?rms can internalize the externalities of security investments and mitigate the security investment ine?ciency.

For policy evaluation, we conducted two large-scale experiments to examine the effectiveness of various policy implementations. In the first quasi-experiment on 1,718 autonomous systems in eight countries, we published security information on http://classic.spamrankings.net. In the website, we regularly released information on the organizations with the worst security behaviors, imposing reputation loss on them. We found that the treatment group subject to information disclosure reduced outgoing spam approximately by 16%. We also found that the more observed outgoing spam from the top spammers, the less likely an organization would be to reduce its own outgoing spam, consistent with the prediction by social comparison theory. In the second randomized field experiment on 7,919 US organizations, we implemented two distinct treatments: private and public. For the privately treated organizations, we provided security reports without public release. Then for the publicly treated ones, we provided the security reports as well as publication on our http://cloud.spamrankings.net website. Our results show that security information alone does not have signi?cant in?uence, while the combination of information and publicity motivates large spammers to change their security strategies. In particular, we found that top 25% spammers have significantly reduced their outbound spam volume by 30%. Furthermore, we observed significant peer effect where organizations are influenced by their peers in the same industry sectors.

With the positive results from the experiments, we plan to take one step forward to set up a nationwide institution sponsored by the government to monitor and evaluate all organizations’ security conditions. The institution will monitor all organizations’ security performances such as spam, phishing, and DDoS attacks and publish them on its public website. From the data, the institution can provide transparent information about organizations’ security levels. In this way, the evaluation agency works the same as Moody’s or S&P do for bonds.
